document_data.name: A Somewhat Honest Merchant's Say
document_data.author: [[Hammeth Ilcarth]]
document_data.mainbody:
'''''A Somewhat Honest Merchant's Say''''' was [[book]] penned by [[Hammeth Ilcarth]] of [[Telflamm]] in the early 14{{th}} century [[DR]]. {{quote|''Look to your [[priest]]s and prayers and altars, for salvation comes from the [[god]]s. All aid, all beauty, all fortune and reward and plenty. It almost makes up for the beasts and bloodshed and heart-ravages they also send.
When red war sweeps the land and [[sword]]s rise, is it not curious that every third warrior calls on this god or that, and swears divine favor is with him?
Yet the blood runs, and whenever one war falters, another bursts forth. Truly, the gods must starve for entertainment.''|Excerpt from ''A Somewhat Honest Merchant's Say''}}
document_data.History: ''A Somewhat Honest Merchant's Say'' collected musings, thoughts, and sayings of Hammeth Ilcarth, a merchant from [[Thesk]]. The book was published in the {{YearlinkName|1339}} and included the author's thoughts on godhood and worship. Hammeth came to conclusion that deities were entertained by wars and strife of the [[Toril]]lian mortals.
